description.narrative: The 2019 CoP covers 2 interlinked reporting periods: 1. The annual reporting period (1 January 2019-31 December 2019)2. The drought response reporting period (1 November 2019 - 28 February 2020) Results from the annual reporting period (January 2019-December 2019) include: 1. The Gender Sensitive Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment (GCVCA) has been completed followed by the development of village-based contingency plans. With regards to the latter, 73% of 2019 targets have been completed. Unfortunately, the process of developing village-based contingency plans has been interrupted by severe drought that struck Somaliland in mid-2019 and consequently, the community’s priorities have shifted to life-saving interventions. 2. A total of 183 Village Savings and Loans Associations (VSLAs) groups were established across the project regions, which represents 68% of the annual target. 3. In addition to the establishment of the VSLAs, a total of 87 VSLA groups with 739 individual members have been trained on money saving methodology, fundamental principles and schedule of operations of VSLA. This represents 35% of targeted value for the reporting period. 4. Moreover, 22 groups (11% of 2019 targeted value) with 375 members have been given an additional training on good hygiene practices aimed towards improving the sanitation and hygiene status of the household with the overall objective of changing the behavior and attitude of the beneficiaries. 5. Furthermore, 21 groups (11% of 2019 target value) with 520 members have been trained in life skills and gender empowerment topics while 20 groups (63% of 2019 targeted value) with 360 members have been trained in good nutrition practices. 6. In the reporting period the project has nearly completed (73%) the registration of beneficiaries for Cash for Work (cfW) activities. 94% of targeted beneficiaries implement CfW projects through conditional cash in line with Community Action Adaptation Plans (CAAPs). 7. The project made good progress with establishing Pastoral and Farmer Field Schools (P/FFS), Fishermen’s group and related training curricula to enhance livelihood diversification through the restoration and protection of productive assets, value chains and the uptake and adoption of agricultural technologies. The targets set for 2019 in relation to FFS has been achieved at 83%. 100 farmers (100% target) have received relevant training and 76% of targeted farmers in the reporting period received agricultural inputs. Unfortunately, targets in relation to kitchen gardens and youth training and skills development have not been met. Following an initial assessment on youth skills needs and enterprise placement requirements, only 18% of 2019 targeted value were able to graduate during the reporting period. 8. The project team has completed the mapping of demand and supply for water resources for livestock, agricultural and household needs. Unfortunately, only 3% (1 out of 31 targeted structure for 2019) have been rehabilitated during the reporting period. The remaining infrastructure will be rehabilitated in the following year (2020). 9. With regards to program learning and research, the first Annual Resilience Measurement (ARM) study was conducted. Key findings include a significant increase in food security between 2017 and 2019, a strong correlation between HH dietary diversity and VSLA ownership, the existence of gender disparities regarding ownership of assets and the necessity of further inclusion of social, cultural and local factors in respect of targeting beneficiaries. Additionally, the project was able to support the Resilience Innovation Lab (RIL) by conducting meetings with donors and learning institutions. Results from the drought response (1 November 2019 to 28 February 2020) The drought response was a four month emergency intervention from November 2019 to February 2020, and was implemented across Awdal Region (Lughaya), North West (Salahley) and Khatumo village in Odweyne in Somaliland. Core activities implemented included unconditional cash transfers (UCT), cash for work (CfW), water trucking and the construction of a communal berkad. The response was undertaken by 2 of the SOMREP consortium partners, World Vision and DRC. The key achievements were: 1. A total of 828 vulnerable households (520 female, 308 male) were reached with unconditional cash transfers. Three cycles of cash distributions were conducted between November and December 2019 during which each household received $105 per month. 2. In response to the water scarcity endured by the Garaaca community of Lughaya, the programme delivered a total of 880,000 litres of water to 300 households (162 female-headed, 138 male-headed). Each household received 133 litre per day for 22 days. 3. Using community-based targeting, DRC reached 1,025 beneficiaries (468 male, 557 female) through Cash for Work (CfW). Of the total beneficiaries reached (1,025), 500 received three cash payments, while the other 525 received one payment as per the January budget revision. As a result of this, 35 hectares of pastureland was rehabilitated through earth works including terracing, erosion control measures and check dams. 4. In addition, 8 garbage pits were dug to dispose and promote clean environment. Furthermore, the enhanced purchasing power of the beneficiaries helped stimulate the small businesses in the target area as the cash flow was improved through the unconditional and conditional cash transfers to the beneficiaries. 5. To address the recurring water shortages, a communal berkad was constructed with the overall objective of harnessing surface rainwater and storing it for use by both livestock and humans in Khatumo Village. The communal berkad has an estimated water capacity of 467 cubic meter which can serve 800 (323 male, 477 female) beneficiaries (of which 200 beneficiaries are IDPs) and about 6,000 heads of livestock (sheep, goat, camel) for at least 3 months. The newly constructed communal berkad also ensures that beneficiaries are able to access a close water source instead of having to travel long distances. The M&E unit conducted post distribution monitoring assessments (PDMs) after each cycle during the drought response. The aim of the assessment was to get beneficiary perception as well their feedback on the distributions to inform about program quality. According to the PDM findings, beneficiaries reported that they were satisfied with cash as means of support and expressed their preference to receive cash rather than food/goods. COVID-19 Response: Though the drought response intervention was successful, there was a remaining balance of SEK 474,474.66 which SomReP has requested to allocate to support COVID-19 activities mostly related to messaging, hygiene and business facilitation. During the COVID-19 period, SomReP has attempted to leverage its role as a platform to identify and scale best practice by providing standard sanitation interventions, including locally purchased soap coupled with hand-washing stations. Also, the program is piloting the use of internet-enabled tablets as a means to deliver COVID-19 messages through the Early Warning Committees at community level. In addition, the program further aims to develop and disseminate COVID-19 awareness information through the Somalia Resilience Innovation Lab (SomRIL) that is hosted by the programme to deliver hygiene messaging through traditional and social media platforms. SomReP has since supported the development of several videos and accompanying posters, and radio drama, and piloting the use of Surprise Soap (a soap with a toy inside) that has proven to be very effective and supporting behaviour change in hand washing practices especially for children who can be carriers/transimtters of the virus and other infectious diseases.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 I slutet av 2019, förväntas cirka 200 parlamentariker och parlamentarisk personal i Sydostasien ha ökad kapacitet i lagstiftnings- och demokratisk utveckling. Kapaciteten hos parlamentariker i Sydostasien att engagera sig på ett konstruktivt sätt i lagstiftningsprocessen kommer att förstärkas genom tillhandahållande av forskningsprodukter som följer standardmetoder för parlamentarisk forskning globalt och genom regionalt utbyte. De regionala aktiviteterna kommer att omfatta utbildningar inom parlamentarisk forskning, engelska, juridisk analys, lagberedning, riksdagskommunikation, utvärdering, parlamentariska budgetanalys, regionala jämförelsetal, regionalt informationsutbyte samt nätverk och seminarier. Mer välutrustade med kunskap kommer parlamenten bli bättre svara på behov från den lokala verkligheten. Kapacitetsuppbyggnad förväntas så småningom att leda till en bättre fördelning av makt, en förbättrad hantering av motstridiga intressen och effektiva system för maktfördelning som nyckelfaktorer för ökad styrning.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 By the end of 2019, about 200 parliamentarians and parliamentary staff in Southeast Asia have increased capacity in legislative and democratic development in the region. The capacity of parliamentarians in Southeast Asia to engage constructively in the legislative process will be strengthened through the provision of research products which follow standard practices for parliamentary research services globally and the provision of regional exchange. The regional activities will comprise trainings for regional fellows on parliamentary research, English, legal analysis, legislative drafting, parliamentary communications, public policy evaluation, parliamentary budget analysis, regional comparatives studies, regional information exchange network, and seminars. The parliaments with well-equipped knowledge will be better respond to the constituents’ needs and local reality. Capacity building will eventually lead to a better sharing of power, an improved management of conflicting interests and effective systems of checks and balances as key elements for enhanced governance.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

description.narrative: In the time of pandemic, PIC training and workshop programs have been shifted online. There were some activities to be highlighted in 2020 as followed: The General Assembly of the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly (AIPA) was held virtually from 8 to 10 September 2020. As the AIPA Member Parliaments adopted to renew the MoU between AIPA and PIC on “Capacity development program for staff of the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly Member Parliaments” during the 40th General Assembly of AIPA in Bangkok in 2019, PIC was invited to attend the 2020 General Assembly to provide the update of their activities. Fitting well with the theme, the PIC capacity building program on parliamentary diplomacy, delivered to members of staff from participating AIPA Member Parliaments, were shared to the conference. The virtual Training Seminar on Parliamentary Responsibilities was finalized on 6 November 2020. 48 participants have been awarded a certificate of completion and participation. This seminar served as a platform for the exchange of knowledge and sharing of best practices on the three core functions of the Parliament: legislation, representation and oversight. Key takeaways include: appreciating the diverse structure of parliamentary systems and its practices; ways to bridge the gap between the parliament and its citizens through the representation function; and tools used by Parliaments to provide checks and balances on the government. Another point of discussion was parliamentary diplomacy, a valuable tool to strengthen international relations within the ASEAN region and beyond. An online training workshop on “Parliamentary Committee Work”, was held from 16 to 18 November. This virtual training workshop’s topics mainly focused on the functions and types of committees in different parliaments, the practical work of parliamentary committees and the work of parliamentary staff to support them. The “Regional Training of Trainers Program”, an online workshop was hosted from 30 November to 4 December 2020, delivered in cooperation with the University of Sussex Department of Education. The participants were staff from ASEAN Inter-parliamentary Assembly (AIPA) Member Parliaments, including Myanmar, Cambodia, the Philippines and Thailand. The main objectives of the training were to improve the quality of individual and institutional pedagogic skills, and to examine the challenges and opportunities of training design. It is important to note that at the time of writing, the PIC annual report for 2020 is not due yet. More results can be reported after April 2021.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Asia Pacific Forum for Women, Law, and Development (APWLD) har ansökt om finansiering om 46 300 000 SEK till Svenska Ambassaden i Bangkok för att genomföra deras strategiska plan för perioden 2017-2021.
Initiativet syftar till att 1) stärka feministiska rörelser på lokal, nationell och regional nivå med särskilt fokus på de mest marginaliserade grupperna, 2) förstärka och utöka kvinnorättsaktivisters- i Asien och Stilla havsorådets- röst, inflytande och påverkan på lokala, nationella, regionala och globala policy organ, 3) Underlätta produktionen av bevisbaserad forskning och verktyg för kvinnorättsaktivisters rörelseuppbyggnad och slutligen 4) bygga upp kapaciteten hos kvinnorättsorganisationers och rörelser i regionen med hjälp av rättighetsbaserade arbetssätt och perspektiv.
Målgruppen för stödet är 60-80 gräsrotsorganisationer som representerar urfolks, migrantgruppers samt kvinnor i urbana och rurala områdens kvinnorättsrörelser. Omkring 25% av den totala budgeten kanaliseras till slutmålgruppen samt en stöd/akutfond för kvinnorättsaktivister.

participating-org.narrative: APWLD/Asia Pacific Forum on Women, Law and Development

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sveriges ambassad i Lusaka har genom det regionala SRHR-teamet fått ett gemensamt programförslag med budget om totalt 400 000 000 SEK från UNAIDS, UNFPA, UNICEF och WHO för att genomföra en regional insats vars mål är att förbättra alla människors sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa och rättigheter, med särskilt fokus på unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper i östra och södra Afrika. Insatsen som genomförs gemensamt av de fyra organisationerna bygger på organisationernas unika styrkor och mandat och har följande specifika mål för perioden 2017-2021:
1. Stödja länder i östra och södra Afrika i att skapa ett politiskt och legalt ramverk som ger alla människor, men särskilt unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper möjlighet att utöva sina rättigheter avseende sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och få tillgång integrerade SRHR/HIV och SGBV-tjänster. 2. Stödja länder i östra och södra Afrika i att tillhandahålla kvalitativa, klientanpassade, integrerade och hållbara SRHR/HIV och SGBV-tjänster, som tillgodoser alla människors behov, med fokus på unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper. 3. Stödja länder i östra och södra Afrika i att stärka alla människor, med fokus på unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper, att utöva sina SRH-rättigheter, anta säkra beteenden och få tillgång till kvalitativa integrerade tjänster i rätt tid. 4. Sprida erfarenheterna från genomförandet av den FN-gemensamma regionala insatsen för att stärka integrerade SRHR/HIV och SGBV-tjänster för alla människor, särskilt unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper i östra och södra Afrika.
Genom att stärka synergierna mellan SRHR, HIV och SGBV-tjänster får länderna möjlighet att hantera flera sammanlänkade hälsobehov hos befolkningen. Detta inbegriper inte bara behov av tillgång till preventivmedel bland kvinnor i reproduktiv ålder, förebyggande av oönskade graviditeter bland kvinnor som lever med HIV, utökad förlossningsvård men också utökning av ART-behandling för HIV-smittade och förebyggande av nya HIV-infektioner. Dessa insatser förväntas leda till förbättrad hälsa för män, kvinnor och barn. För att stärka det regionala arbetet har fem fokusländer valts ut, Lesotho, Malawi, Uganda, Zambia och Zimbabwe. Ytterligare fyra länder, Botswana, Kenya, Namibia och Swaziland, som var fokusländer i Linkages-projektet som Sverige tidigare stött genom det regionala SRHR-teamet, fortsätter att få begränsat stöd och fungera som modell för andra. De fyra FN-organisationerna avser samarbeta för att ge katalytiskt stöd till regionala ekonomiska gemenskaper, civilsamhällsorganisationer och lokalsamhällen som en del av den regionala ansatsen att adressera flera olika SRHR-utmaningar inklusive oönskade graviditeter, könsrelaterat sexuellt våld, sexuellt överförbara sjukdomar inkl. HIV samt mödradödlighet.
Sidas avtalspart för insatsen är UNFPA som i sin tur inått ett MOU med UNAIDS, UNICEF och WHO. Avtalsstrukturen baseras på fastställd modell för "Pass-Through Fund Management Modality" med UNFPA som "Administrative Agent" (AA) och "Convening Agent" (CA), i enlighet med United Nations Development Groups (UNDG) riktlinjer från 2015. UNFPAs enhet för "Communication and Strategic Partherships" kommer ha roll som AA medan UNFPA ESARO har ansvar som CA. I enlighet med avtalsmodellen har parterna var och en fullt ansvar för sin del av tilldelade medel och resultat i enlighet med respektive organisations regelverk, policyer och rutiner. Sidas formella kontakt med alla FN-organisationer sker genom UNFPA och eventuella utestående frågor kanaliseras därigenom.
En regional styrkommitté (bestående av deltagande FN-organisationer, representanter för deltagande länders regeringar, regionala civilsamhällesorganisationer samt regionala ekonomiska gemenskaper är det högsta beslutande organet för insatsen. Sida deltar som observatör i styrkommittén som sammanträder en gång per år. Därutöver kommer det finnas en regional samordningsmekanism mellan deltagande FN-organisationer som också ansvarar för gemensam teknisk rådgivning till deltagande länder samt för att ta fram kunskapsmaterial kring SRHR/HIV och SGBV integrering. På landnivå kommer motsvarande styrkommittéer inrättas för koordinering, kontroll och strategisk vägledning.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Embassy of Sweden in Lusaka, through the Regional SRHR Team, (Team) has received a joint funding proposal amounting to SEK 400 000 000 from the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), United Nations Children’s Fund UNICEF), and World Health Organization (WHO) to implement a regional intervention whose goal is to improve the sexual and reproductive health and rights of all people, but with a particular focus on adolescent girls, young people and key populations in the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) region. Specifically, the main collaborating partners are UNFPA Eastern and Southern Africa Regional Office (UNFPA ESARO), UNAIDS Regional Support Team for East and Southern Africa (UNAIDS RST- ESA), UNICEF East and Southern Africa Regional Office (UNICEF ESARO) and WHO Regional Office for Africa (WHO AFRO). The joint intervention draws on the four agencies' unique strengths and mandates and has the following specific objectives:
1. Support countries in the ESA region to create an enabling legal and policy environment by 2021 that empowers all people, but particularly adolescent girls, young people and key populations to exercise their SRH rights and access quality integrated SRHR/HIV and SGBV services. 2. Support countries in the ESA region to scale up the provision of client- centred quality assured, integrated and sustainable SRHR/HIV and SGBV services, by 2021 that meet the needs of all people, in particular adolescent girls, young people and key populations. 3. Support countries in the ESA region to empower all people, but with a focus on adolescent girls, young people and key populations to exercise their SRH rights, adopt protective behaviours, and access quality integrated services in a timely manner, by 2021. 4. Amplify the lessons learnt from the implementation of the Joint UN Regional Intervention to strengthen integrated SRHR/HIV and SGBV services for all people in particular adolescent girls, youth and key populations in the ESA Region, by 2021.
In particular, increasing the synergies between SRH and HIV services provides countries with the opportunity to address the multiple, inter-linked health needs of clients.This includes addressing not only the unmet need for family planning among women of reproductive age, preventing unintended pregnancies among women living with HIV, and expanding antenatal care, but also scaling up life-saving ART treatment and preventing new HIV infections. These efforts ultimately translate into improved health outcomes for men, women, and children. In reinforcing the regional effort, five focus countries have been selected, namely: Lesotho, Malawi, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe. An additional four countries i.e. Botswana, Kenya, Namibia and Swaziland, which were focus countries on the Linkages Project that Sweden previously supported through the regional SRHR Team, will continue to receive limited support and serve as model countries for others. The four UN agencies aim to take a collaborative approach in providing catalytic support to regional economic communities (RECs) governments, civil society organisations and communities as part of the regional effort to address various SRHR challenges including unintended pregnancies, SGBV, STIs and HIV and maternal mortality.
Sida's agreement partner for the intervention is UNFPA, which has entered into Memorandum of Understanding (MoUs) with UNAIDS, UNICEF and WHO. The agreement structure is based on the Pass-Through Fund Management Modality model with UNFPA serving as both the Administrative Agent (AA) and the Convening Agent (CA) in accordance with the 2015 United Nations Development Group (UNDG) guidelines. Specifically, the Division of Communication and Strategic Partnerships will be responsible for the AA functions while UNFPA ESARO will manage the organisation's CA role.
All planning, budgeting, monitoring and reporting processes are based on the provisions of the Standard Administrative Arrangement (SAA), the prescribed UNDG agreement structure for this intervention. Under this contractual set-up, each participating UN agency will be fully responsible for its share of assigned funds and results in accordance with its own regulations, policies and procedures. Sida's formal contact with all the participating UN agencies is through UNFPA.
A regional programme steering committee (RPSC) consisting of participating UN agencies, representatives of participating countries, regional civil society organizations and selected regional economic communities (RECs) is the highest decision-making body for the intervention. Sida will be participating as an observer in the RPSC meetings to be held annually. In addition, there will be a regional coordination mechanism of the participating UN agencies i.e. the Regional Inter-agency Working Group (RIWG) that will be providing joint technical support to the participating countries and will also be involved in developing knowledge products to advance learning on SRHR/HIV and SGBV integration. At country level, national steering committees will be similarly established for coordination, fiduciary and management oversight, and to provide strategic guidance.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Building on the progress recorded particularly in the second half of the previous year, the following are some of the achievements recorded in 2019: OBJECTIVE 1: Creating an enabling legal and policy environment for SRHR. At continental level, the programme partnered with the Pan-African Parliament to sensitize parliamentarians and senior government officials on how the legal barriers for key populations (KPs) and youth to access SRHR services undermine health outcomes. Participants renewed their commitment to ensure access to SRHR services for KPs and young people. Lawmakers were urged to draft laws against SBGV and harmful practices, and to mobilize national resources for the health sector through mechanisms such as national health insurance, tax and fiscal space, and corporate social responsibility. Using the Nairobi International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD 25) platform, the programme contributed to the Ministers of Health for the East African Community (EAC) adopting a Joint Ministerial Commitment delivered by the Chairperson of the EAC Council of Ministers during the Conference. Ministers committed themselves to ensure universal access to sexual, reproductive, maternal and neonatal, child and adolescent health, address the high unmet need for family planning, reduce teenage pregnancy, eliminate mother to child transmission of HIV, address GBV, and ensure a region free of HIV, sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and tuberculosis (TB). Through engagement with the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) and a consortium of civil society partners led by the East African Network of AIDS Service Organizations (EANASO) and Faith 2 Action, the programme contributed to the revitalisation of the EAC SRHR Bill. A road map that includes working with the General Purpose Committee of EALA on concerns relating to the Bill was subsequently developed. Similar engagements with policy makers and legislators were successfully held in various countries in the review period. For instance, Lesotho conducted two advocacy sessions with four parliamentary committees (social cluster, SRHR/HIV, governance, and SDGs) to review the Child Marriage and the Domestic Violence Bills. The programme also supported oversight visits by members of the parliamentary committees to three health facilities in the implementing districts. In Malawi, two advocacy meetings were held with parliamentarians, who subsequently identified MPs to be Maputo Protocol Champions and in Zimbabwe, an advocacy session to discuss legal and other barriers to access SRHR services, unsafe abortion and lack of domestic financing for contraceptives, among other issues, was attended by 80 MPs. In the year under review, some progress was made in the domestication of the SADC SRHR Strategy and SRHR Score Card approved in 2018. In Botswana, discussions were held on how to link the national RAMNCH strategy to the SADC SRHR Strategy, Eswatini supported orientation sessions with the National SRHR CSO Consortium on the SADC SRHR Scorecard and Lesotho developed a national SRMNCAH Scorecard in line with the SADC SRHR Scorecard indicators. Targeting lawmakers at various levels is a critical step in the creation of a favourable legal and policy environment for SRHR, HIV and SGBV by enhancing the capacity to address discrimination, promote progressive laws and allocating more domestic resources during the budgeting process. In this regard, more could be done to ensure the advocacy work and capacity building efforts linked to particular policy processes do not end up as stand-alone interventions but contribute to positive transformation, however slow the shift may be. OBJECTIVE 2: Strengthening the delivery of quality integrated SRHR Services. In the year under review, the bulk of the funds earmarked for this objective went towards building health worker (HW) capacity to deliver integrated SRHR/HIV/SGBV services, to integrate family planning into different service delivery points, and to address HW norms and attitudes related to adolescents, abortion, and key populations. By the end of the year, 500 HWs had been trained to provide integrated SRH/HIV/SGBV services, 200 HWs trained on adolescent and youth-friendly services (AYFHS) and 681 HWs trained on integrating family planning in various service delivery points. A regional capacity building platform has been established, in partnership with IPAS, to strengthen the capacity of countries to address HW norms, values and attitudes towards abortion, and to provide training on the clinical aspects of safe abortion care in the context of the legal framework of the country concerned. By the end of the year, 70 trainers were trained in Botswana, Eswatini and Malawi to conduct trainings on values clarification/attitude transformation (VCAT) to transform HCW norms, values and attitude in relation to abortion services and at least 420 HWs trained to provide comprehensive and post-abortion care in four countries. These interventions complement other direct and indirect contributions that the 2gether 4 SRHR programme continues to make to towards reducing the maternal mortality and morbidity burden associated with unsafe abortion in the region. The programme's health system strengthening approach includes testing and supporting the scale up of service delivery models for integrated services. In the period under review, Botswana succesfully scaled up the provision of integrated SRHR services using its three models of integration (Kiosk, Supermarket and Mall) to 13 districts. In Zimbabwe, the programme supports health facilities in 13 districts to provide integrated SRHR, HIV and GBV services through capacity building and supportive supervision. An assessment of the capacity to provide integrated services services was conducted in 46 health facilities across the 13 districts and the findings revealed that the main barriers include scarce human resources (in numbers and skills), shortages of medicines, and limited space for privacy. The assessment led to the development of site-specific scale up workplans that were consolidated into district and provincial plans to be implemented in 2020. From the outset, it was noted that regional M&E tools to track and report on progress made against regional and international commitments were in most cases, weak resulting in a lack of reporting and accountability in meeting these commitments. At national and sub-national levels, gaps noted include the lack of timely, dissagregated SRHR, SGBV data mainstreamed in the routine health management information systems (HMIS) to inform decision-making. To address some of theses challenges, the programme in the reporting period supported the governments of Malawi and Zimbabwe to launch the integrated Health Situation Rooms (HSR), data visualisation and analysis platforms to support facility level decision making for policy makers and programme managers, bringing the cumulative number of focus countries with HSRs to six. This has resulted in improvements and harmonization of programme monitoring systems and identification of gaps in service provision within health facilities. OBJECTIVE 3. Strengthened communication, ownership, empowerment and participation Results achieved under this objective were predominantly at country level. For instance, in Eswatini more than 300 young people were reached with information of SRHR through church meetings and 27 monthly community dialogue meetings were held in four districts in Uganda to raise awareness on SRHR issues, and other countries utilised a range of similar strategies to engage decision makers, traditional, religious and community leaders to advocate for policy reforms and changes in norms. In Uganda,the programme supported the Organization of African First Ladies for Development (OAFLAD) to convene political, cultural and religious leaders and organizations to discuss SRHR/HIV integration and the National Multisectoral Adolescent Girl Framework. Following this event, eight major religious denominations in the country developed pastoral letters on HIV, FP, maternal health, teenage pregnancy and FGM. In Zambia, a supporte to a network of 40 men's clubs to conduct weekly out-of-school CSE sessions in four districts resulted in 3,900 boys and 1,430 young men reached. Objective 4: Amplify lessons learned on SRHR, HIV and SGBV Integration During the reporting period, various strategies were used to amplify lessons learned from implementing the integration agenda. A cross-journal supplement to Reproductive Health and BMC Public Health Journals was published on the Effective Integration of Sexual Reproductive Health and HIV Prevention, Treatment, and Care Services across sub-Saharan Africa: Where is the evidence for program implementation? This was jointly published with USAID West and Central Africa, and the Infectious Diseases and Epidemiology Department at Johns Hopkins University, Bloomberg School of Public Health. Further, the programme supported a number of exchange visits both across and within countriesto facilitate learning. For instance, Botswana visited Eswatini to learn about the harmonization of SRHR data collection tools and registers and how stakeholders use data to drive programme improvement and decision making. The visit resulted in a strategic information group being established at the MoH to drive the process of creating an integrated electronic client management system to improve health outcomes. Using the standard programme guide developed by the joint regional management team, Kenya and Malawi succesfuly produced video and photo human interest stories and in Botswana, the success of Letsholathebe Memorial Hospital II and Ngami district in reducing maternal mortality was documented as a best practice. It is expected that with intensified programming in the next two years, more evidence on impact will be generated and disseminated to an even wider audience through various platforms including international conferences and social media.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Embassy of Sweden in Lusaka, through the Regional SRHR Team, (Team) has received a joint funding proposal amounting to SEK 400 000 000 from the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), United Nations Children’s Fund UNICEF), and World Health Organization (WHO) to implement a regional intervention whose goal is to improve the sexual and reproductive health and rights of all people, but with a particular focus on adolescent girls, young people and key populations in the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) region. Specifically, the main collaborating partners are UNFPA Eastern and Southern Africa Regional Office (UNFPA ESARO), UNAIDS Regional Support Team for East and Southern Africa (UNAIDS RST- ESA), UNICEF East and Southern Africa Regional Office (UNICEF ESARO) and WHO Regional Office for Africa (WHO AFRO). The joint intervention draws on the four agencies' unique strengths and mandates and has the following specific objectives:
1. Support countries in the ESA region to create an enabling legal and policy environment by 2021 that empowers all people, but particularly adolescent girls, young people and key populations to exercise their SRH rights and access quality integrated SRHR/HIV and SGBV services. 2. Support countries in the ESA region to scale up the provision of client- centred quality assured, integrated and sustainable SRHR/HIV and SGBV services, by 2021 that meet the needs of all people, in particular adolescent girls, young people and key populations. 3. Support countries in the ESA region to empower all people, but with a focus on adolescent girls, young people and key populations to exercise their SRH rights, adopt protective behaviours, and access quality integrated services in a timely manner, by 2021. 4. Amplify the lessons learnt from the implementation of the Joint UN Regional Intervention to strengthen integrated SRHR/HIV and SGBV services for all people in particular adolescent girls, youth and key populations in the ESA Region, by 2021.
In particular, increasing the synergies between SRH and HIV services provides countries with the opportunity to address the multiple, inter-linked health needs of clients.This includes addressing not only the unmet need for family planning among women of reproductive age, preventing unintended pregnancies among women living with HIV, and expanding antenatal care, but also scaling up life-saving ART treatment and preventing new HIV infections. These efforts ultimately translate into improved health outcomes for men, women, and children. In reinforcing the regional effort, five focus countries have been selected, namely: Lesotho, Malawi, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe. An additional four countries i.e. Botswana, Kenya, Namibia and Swaziland, which were focus countries on the Linkages Project that Sweden previously supported through the regional SRHR Team, will continue to receive limited support and serve as model countries for others. The four UN agencies aim to take a collaborative approach in providing catalytic support to regional economic communities (RECs) governments, civil society organisations and communities as part of the regional effort to address various SRHR challenges including unintended pregnancies, SGBV, STIs and HIV and maternal mortality.
Sida's agreement partner for the intervention is UNFPA, which has entered into Memorandum of Understanding (MoUs) with UNAIDS, UNICEF and WHO. The agreement structure is based on the Pass-Through Fund Management Modality model with UNFPA serving as both the Administrative Agent (AA) and the Convening Agent (CA) in accordance with the 2015 United Nations Development Group (UNDG) guidelines. Specifically, the Division of Communication and Strategic Partnerships will be responsible for the AA functions while UNFPA ESARO will manage the organisation's CA role.
All planning, budgeting, monitoring and reporting processes are based on the provisions of the Standard Administrative Arrangement (SAA), the prescribed UNDG agreement structure for this intervention. Under this contractual set-up, each participating UN agency will be fully responsible for its share of assigned funds and results in accordance with its own regulations, policies and procedures. Sida's formal contact with all the participating UN agencies is through UNFPA.
A regional programme steering committee (RPSC) consisting of participating UN agencies, representatives of participating countries, regional civil society organizations and selected regional economic communities (RECs) is the highest decision-making body for the intervention. Sida will be participating as an observer in the RPSC meetings to be held annually. In addition, there will be a regional coordination mechanism of the participating UN agencies i.e. the Regional Inter-agency Working Group (RIWG) that will be providing joint technical support to the participating countries and will also be involved in developing knowledge products to advance learning on SRHR/HIV and SGBV integration. At country level, national steering committees will be similarly established for coordination, fiduciary and management oversight, and to provide strategic guidance.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sveriges ambassad i Lusaka har genom det regionala SRHR-teamet fått ett gemensamt programförslag med budget om totalt 400 000 000 SEK från UNAIDS, UNFPA, UNICEF och WHO för att genomföra en regional insats vars mål är att förbättra alla människors sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa och rättigheter, med särskilt fokus på unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper i östra och södra Afrika. Insatsen som genomförs gemensamt av de fyra organisationerna bygger på organisationernas unika styrkor och mandat och har följande specifika mål för perioden 2017-2021:
1. Stödja länder i östra och södra Afrika i att skapa ett politiskt och legalt ramverk som ger alla människor, men särskilt unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper möjlighet att utöva sina rättigheter avseende sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och få tillgång integrerade SRHR/HIV och SGBV-tjänster. 2. Stödja länder i östra och södra Afrika i att tillhandahålla kvalitativa, klientanpassade, integrerade och hållbara SRHR/HIV och SGBV-tjänster, som tillgodoser alla människors behov, med fokus på unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper. 3. Stödja länder i östra och södra Afrika i att stärka alla människor, med fokus på unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper, att utöva sina SRH-rättigheter, anta säkra beteenden och få tillgång till kvalitativa integrerade tjänster i rätt tid. 4. Sprida erfarenheterna från genomförandet av den FN-gemensamma regionala insatsen för att stärka integrerade SRHR/HIV och SGBV-tjänster för alla människor, särskilt unga flickor, unga vuxna och nyckelgrupper i östra och södra Afrika.
Genom att stärka synergierna mellan SRHR, HIV och SGBV-tjänster får länderna möjlighet att hantera flera sammanlänkade hälsobehov hos befolkningen. Detta inbegriper inte bara behov av tillgång till preventivmedel bland kvinnor i reproduktiv ålder, förebyggande av oönskade graviditeter bland kvinnor som lever med HIV, utökad förlossningsvård men också utökning av ART-behandling för HIV-smittade och förebyggande av nya HIV-infektioner. Dessa insatser förväntas leda till förbättrad hälsa för män, kvinnor och barn. För att stärka det regionala arbetet har fem fokusländer valts ut, Lesotho, Malawi, Uganda, Zambia och Zimbabwe. Ytterligare fyra länder, Botswana, Kenya, Namibia och Swaziland, som var fokusländer i Linkages-projektet som Sverige tidigare stött genom det regionala SRHR-teamet, fortsätter att få begränsat stöd och fungera som modell för andra. De fyra FN-organisationerna avser samarbeta för att ge katalytiskt stöd till regionala ekonomiska gemenskaper, civilsamhällsorganisationer och lokalsamhällen som en del av den regionala ansatsen att adressera flera olika SRHR-utmaningar inklusive oönskade graviditeter, könsrelaterat sexuellt våld, sexuellt överförbara sjukdomar inkl. HIV samt mödradödlighet.
Sidas avtalspart för insatsen är UNFPA som i sin tur inått ett MOU med UNAIDS, UNICEF och WHO. Avtalsstrukturen baseras på fastställd modell för "Pass-Through Fund Management Modality" med UNFPA som "Administrative Agent" (AA) och "Convening Agent" (CA), i enlighet med United Nations Development Groups (UNDG) riktlinjer från 2015. UNFPAs enhet för "Communication and Strategic Partherships" kommer ha roll som AA medan UNFPA ESARO har ansvar som CA. I enlighet med avtalsmodellen har parterna var och en fullt ansvar för sin del av tilldelade medel och resultat i enlighet med respektive organisations regelverk, policyer och rutiner. Sidas formella kontakt med alla FN-organisationer sker genom UNFPA och eventuella utestående frågor kanaliseras därigenom.
En regional styrkommitté (bestående av deltagande FN-organisationer, representanter för deltagande länders regeringar, regionala civilsamhällesorganisationer samt regionala ekonomiska gemenskaper är det högsta beslutande organet för insatsen. Sida deltar som observatör i styrkommittén som sammanträder en gång per år. Därutöver kommer det finnas en regional samordningsmekanism mellan deltagande FN-organisationer som också ansvarar för gemensam teknisk rådgivning till deltagande länder samt för att ta fram kunskapsmaterial kring SRHR/HIV och SGBV integrering. På landnivå kommer motsvarande styrkommittéer inrättas för koordinering, kontroll och strategisk vägledning.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

title.narrative: SAT-Moving the Needle:Gender Transformative SRHR Systems in Africa
SAT-Moving the Needle:Gender Transformative SRHR Systems in Africa

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sveriges ambassad i Lusaka, genom det regionala SRHR-teamet, har mottagit en framställan om stöd från SAT (Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights Africa Trust) för att genomföra insatsen, "Moving the Needle: Gender Transformative SRHR Systems in Africa 2018-2024" vars övergripande mål är att kvinnor, flickor och ungdomar bättre kan utöva sina sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter. Följande resultat har identifierats för att uppnå detta övergripande mål:
1. Ökad tillgång till gender transformativa SRHR-system; 2. Förbättrad miljö för SRHR och jämställdhet mellan könen; 3. Ökad ledarskap av tjejer, ungdomar och kvinnor i SRHR-system; och 4. Ökat utnyttjande av könsspecifik data.
SAT grundades 1990 för att stödja lokala organisationer i stärkandet av hiv och aids-program. Sedan dess har organisationens verksamhet utvecklats till att fokusera på SRHR i östra och södra Afrika och samverkar idag med över 100 kommuner/lokalsamhällen, NGOs, lokalorganisationer och aktivister för universell SRHR för flickor, ungdomar och unga kvinnor i inkluderande, rättvisa system för hälsa. Sveriges samarbete med SAT startade 2006 med ett mindre bidrag för sina hiv- och aids-program. 2012 ingick Sverige, genom det regionala SRHR-teamet, ett treårigt avtal om 60 miljoner kronor för kärnstöd till SATs strategi för 2012-2017, vars vision var "Resilient communities across Southern Africa enjoy good health and well-being free of stigma and discrimination." Detta skulle uppnås genom att stärka kapaciteten hos samarbetsparter på lokal nivå att förebygga ungdomar och kvinnors hälsa, att integrera SRHR och hiv i programmering samt dialog om hälsa. Avtalet förlängdes senare två år (2016-2017) med ytterligare 46 MSEK.
Sverige och andra givare bidragit till att stärka SATs kapacitet inom områdena styrning, programmering och internkontroll. Resultat från en oberoende utvärdering som genomfördes i slutet av 2015 visar att SATs modell för att stärka lokala system (Community System Strengthening) bidragit till att lokalsamhällen aktivt tar ansvar för sin egen hälsa. Bland de resultat som framhålls är den förbättrade kvaliteten på hiv- och SRHR-tjänster tack vare SATs ansträngningar för integration, och för att göra hälsovårdstjänster mer ungdomsvänliga. Utvärderingsrapporten drar också slutsatsen att SAT är en väl respekterad, synlig och konstruktiv civil aktör på nationell och regional nivå.
Genom den föreslagna insatsen avser SAT bidra till att adressera flera utvecklingsutmaningar som påverkar flickor, ungdomar och kvinnor i östra och södra Afrika. Dessa inkluderar bristen på könsspecifik SRHR-data vilket bidrar till icke ändamålsenliga åtgärder från regeringar och enskilda organisationer samt överbelastade hälsosystem som kämpar med att nå utsatta och marginaliserade grupper såsom ungdomar i fängelser med adekvat, ungdomsvänlig, målgruppsanpassad information och tjänster. Dessutom står regionen för det högsta antalet nya hiv-infektioner globalt, och ungdomar, särskilt unga kvinnor, drabbas oproportionerligt. Aids är den främsta dödsorsaken bland ungdomar i åldern 15-19 år. Även tonårsgraviditet, barn och tidiga äktenskap samt könsrelaterat våld är bland de främsta orsakerna till bristande SRHR för ungdomar och unga kvinnor. Den växande konservativa politiska agendan är ytterligare ett hot mot de progressiva SRHR-policyförändringar som hittills gjorts i flera länder.
SATs regionala kontor ligger i Johannesburg, Sydafrika, där det också är registrerat som en regional icke-statlig organisation. SAT har också 4 landskontor; i Botswana, Malawi, Zambia och Zimbabwe. SATs styrelse har det övergripande ansvaret för styrning och ledning av regionkontoret och landskontoren. En ledningsgrupp bestående av den verkställande direktören, verksamhetschefen, ekonomichefen (som även rapporterar till styrelsens utskott för ekonomi, revision och risk, FARCO), programchefen och de fyra landscheferna har det övergripande ansvar för den dagliga verksamheten. I genomförandet av insatsen kommer SAT att arbeta med 35 partners i regionen. Samarbetet med partners har olika karaktär och avser bl.a. direkt samarbete, påverkansarbete, innovation eller data. I val av partners har SAT lagt stor vikt vid organisationens förmåga att bidra till effekter på regional nivå. De partners som hittills har identifierats är bland andra African Youth and Adolescent Network on Populations and Development (AfriYAN), Eastern Africa National Networks of AIDS Service Organizations (EANNASO) och Rozaria Memorial Trust. SAT kommer också att samarbeta med en rad regionala organisationer med gemensamma agendor kring SRHR, såsom Afrikanska unionen och SADCs parlamentariska forum (SADC-PF). För att komplettera de regionala ansträngningarna kommer olika nationella interventioner att genomföras genom SATs landskontor.
Ansökan avser kärnstöd om 70 miljoner kronor för perioden 2018-2021. Omkring 12% av finansieringen från Sverige kommer att vidareförmedlas till partner. SAT har hittills säkrat 7,5 miljoner US-dollar från Schweiz genom SDC. Tillsammans med det planerade stödet från Sverige motsvarar det 85% av budgeten för de första fyra åren. Som en del av beredningen uppmanades SAT att presentera åtgärder för att hantera eventuellt finansieringsgap, och en reviderad budget som återspeglar en lägre volym har därefter lämnats in.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Embassy of Sweden in Lusaka, through the Regional SRHR Team, has received a funding proposal from the Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights Africa Trust (SAT) to implement an intervention, "Moving the Needle: Gender Transformative SRHR Systems in Africa 2018-2024" whose overall goal is women, girls and adolescents better able to exercise their SRHR. The following outcomes have been identified as key for the attainment of this overall objective:
1. Increased access to gender transformative SRHR systems; 2. Improved environment for SRHR and gender equality; 3. Increased leadership of adolescent girls, youth, women in SRHR systems; and 4. Increased utilization of gender focused data.
SAT was established in 1990 to support community-based organizations in the strengthening of HIV and AIDS programmes. Since then, the organization has transformed its programming activities to focus on SRHR in Eastern and Southern Africa with over 100 communities, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations (CBOs) and activists working for universal SRHR for girls, adolescents and young women in inclusive, equitable systems for health. Sweden's collaboration with SAT dates to 2006 when the organization was provided with a small grant for its HIV and AIDS programmes. In 2012, Sweden, through the Regional SRHR Team, signed a three-year agreement amounting to SEK 60MSEK for core support towards its 2012-2017 Strategy whose vision was "Resilient communities across Southern Africa enjoy good health and well-being free of stigma and discrimination." This was to be achieved by building the capacity of supported communities in the areas of youth prevention, women’s health, integrated SRHR and HIV programming and dialogue on health. The agreement was later extended for two years (2016-2017) with an additional 46 MSEK.
Over the years, Sweden and other funding partners have made considerable investments in improving SAT's capacity in the areas of governance, programming and internal control environment. Findings from an independent evaluation carried out at the end of 2015 indicate that there is credible evidence showing that SAT’s model of Community Systems Strengthening (CSS) ensures that communities actively take responsibility for their own health. Among the notable achievements highlighted is the improved quality of HIV and SRHR services due to SAT's efforts on integration and making health services more youth-friendly. The evaluation report also concludes that SAT is a well-respected, visible and constructive civil society actor at national and regional level.
By implementing the proposed intervention, the organization seeks to contribute to addressing many developmental challenges affecting women girls and adolescents in the East and Southern Africa (ESA) region. These include the lack of gender sensitive SRHR data, which contributes to inappropriate responses from governments and CSOs, and over-burdened health systems that struggle to reach vulnerable and marginalized groups such as adolescents in prisons with adequate, youth friendly, gender responsive information and services. Further, the region accounts for the highest number of new HIV infections globally, and adolescents and young people, particularly girls, are disproportionately affected. AIDS remains the leading cause of death among youths aged 15 – 19 years. Also, teenage pregnancy, child and early marriages as well as gender-based violence (GBV) are among the root causes of violations of the SRHR of adolescent girls and young women (AGYW). The growing conservative political agenda is yet another threat to the progressive SRHR policy changes that have been made to date in several countries.
SAT's Regional Office is in Johannesburg, South Africa, where it is also registered as a regional NGO. It also operates 4 Country Offices in Botswana, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe. In terms of governance and management, the SAT Board holds overall responsibility for the Regional Office as well as the Country Offices. A senior management team comprising the Executive Director, Chief Operating Officer, Finance Director (who also reports to the Finance Audit and Risk Committee (FARCO)), Programmes Director and the four Country Directors oversees the day-to-day operations. For the implementation of this intervention, SAT will work directly with 35 partners across the ESA region, classified as collaboration, advocacy, innovation, or data partners. As a criterion for selection, SAT has placed more emphasis on the organization’s capacity to make regional contributions and impact. The implementing partners identified to date include African Youth and Adolescent Network on Populations and Development (AfriYAN), Eastern Africa National Networks of AIDS Service Organizations (EANNASO) and Rozaria Memorial Trust. SAT will also collaborate with a range of regional organizations with common agendas around SRHR or putting girls at the centre, such as the African Union and the SADC Parliamentary Forum (SADC-PF). To complement the regional efforts, various national-level interventions will be carried out in SAT's Country Offices.
The funding application is for core support amounting to 70 MSEK for the period 2018-2021. SAT has so far secured US$ 7.5 million core funding from the Swiss Agency for Development Cooperation (SDC). About 12% of the funding from Sweden will be forwarded as sub-grants to various implementing partners. This grant, and the amount anticipated from Sweden will together make up 85% of the strategy budget for the first four years. As part of the appraisal process, SAT was requested to present mitigation measures it would take to address the funding gap, and a revised budget reflecting a reduced shortfall has since been submitted.
The Embassy assesses that the organization has adequate capacity and resources to implement and monitor the intervention and considers the overall risk rating to be medium. To improve the intervention's alignment with Sweden's strategic SRHR objectives and enhance the focus on results based management, it is assessed that project support amounting to 70 MSEK be provided over the four-year period 2018-2021, with a provision in the agreement allowing a one-year transition period (2018-2019) during which the year's disbursement will be in form of core support.
The overall risk rating for the intervention is medium. Apart from the financial risks due to lapses in the internal control environment and the possibility of inadequate resources to fully cover the projected expenditure, the intervention also faces the risk of some intended results not being achieved due to the sensitive nature of the issues involved e.g. safe abortion. However, the mitigation measures proposed by SAT and the inclusion of special clauses in the Agreement to mitigate these risks have been taken into account in arriving at this overall risk profile.
The goal of the intervention is women, girls and adolescents better able to exercise their sexual and reproductive health and rights.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

description.narrative: In 2018, Sweden signed a four-year agreement for financial support to SAT's Strategy, Moving the Needle 2018-2024, whose overall goal is women, girls and adolescents better able to exercise their SRHR. The following outcomes have been identified as key for the attainment of this overall objective: 1. Increased access to gender transformative SRHR systems:2. Improved environment for SRHR and gender equality;3. Increased leadership of adolescent girls, youth, women in SRHR systems; and4. Increased utilization of gender focused data. The period under review (1st April 2018-31 March 2019) represents the first year of the activity period. Following Sweden's shift from core to programme support under the regional SRHR Strategy for 2016-2021, the first year of the grant was considered a transition period to enable SAT to revise the contribution in line with the provisions of programme support agreements. Since the performance measurement framework is undergoing revision, it will be part of subsequent annual reports. Among the results achieved in the course of the year was the development of 16 policy briefs on a range of themes such as adolescent access to SRHR, access to services for gender-based violence and differentiated service delivery for adolescents and young people living with HIV. Apart from enhancing the organisation's advocacy activities, the policy briefs are additional resources for SAT's partners working on the ASRHR agenda in Southern Africa. As a contribution to addressing the needs of juveniles and young people in prisons, SAT has developed a Prison Tracker Tool using unique identifier codes to track their health status. In the reporting period, the tracking tool was introduced in in prisons in Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Data were available for 492 young prisoners. All but two of them were male, and the median age was 18 in Zambia, 19 in Malawi and 20 in Zimbabwe. All prisoners were reported to have received HIV counselling but only 74 percent were tested for HIV and 83 percent were screened for tuberculosis. Of those tested, 14 were found to be HIV positive. Data on HIV treatment were not provided, and further efforts are being made to assure completion of the tracking tool by the prison authorities. Under increasing access to HIV Testing and Treatment, SAT's efforts were mainly focused on HIV awareness and knowledge, young people’s knowledge of their HIV status; access to support groups and safe spaces for young people living with HIV; and access and adherence to anti-retroviral therapy (ART). A total of 18 SAT partners in Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe implemented various programmes and in the reporting period, programme support helped almost 27,000 young women and 19,000 young men to know their HIV status and access HCT services. A number of activities were undertaken to address legal barriers that prevent acess to ASRH services. At national level, the SAT Zimbabwe Country Office organised three national dialogues on SRHR that focused on age of consent and abortion laws while in Zambia, one national dialogue was held in addition to a national advocacy meeting for safe abortion. Partners were also active on policy reform issues at national level. Four partners in Malawi and Zimbabwe developed or supported a total of 15 advocacy platforms dedicated to changing policy on access to health services, and three of them supported a total of 23 advocacy events on the issue of legal age of consent. At regional level, SAT took a leading role in developing civil society inputs into the SADC SRHR strategy on age of consent. The Strategy now provides a strong advocacy platform for the revision of national age of consent legislation in the coming years. Challenges encountered in the reporting period include delays in receiving funding from cooperating partners and growing opposition among governments in the region against adopting or implementing laws designed to protecting the rights of sexual minorities and to removing barriers to accessing sexual health services for adolescents. Financial Report The total core support budget for the period under review was US$ 5 211 033, of which 84% was utilised. Variances were reported on a number of buget lines, among them: -Partner Programming grants (85% budget utilisation): The under-spend on this line was mainly due to the withholding of a proportion of funds due to non-fufilment of agreement conditions by some sub-grantees. -Monitoring and Evaluation (80% budget utilisation): The M&E budget was mainly for a contract with Stellenbosch University for the development of a three-year M&E framework including identification and collection of baseline data. The under-spend is explained by the fact that the final payment was yet to be made by the end of the reporting period.-Programme Salaries (89% budget utilisation): Two positions at the SAT Regional Office (Regional SRHR and Advocacy Coordinator and Regional Adolescent SRHR manager) fell vacant in the course of the year, resulting in the actual expenditure on this budget line being lower than projected. Overspent lines include conferences (110%) and SAT Board operations (107%). The audit report for the year ended 31 March 2019, prepared in accordance with International Standards on Auditing is unqualified. Although the audit report and management letter were due on 30 September 2019, both were were submitted three weeks late on account of delays in completing the exercise. The previous audit report was also submitted late and Sweden has since stressed to SAT the need for adherence to the stipulated submission dates. Audit findings to be followed up in the next reporting period include the delayed retirement of travel advances, provision for a long-standing court case involving a SAT employee and missing donor codes on invoices or requisitions.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNFPA Sexual and reproductive health and rights 2017-2020
COVID-19 UNFPA Sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter 2017-2020

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This contribution is a support to UNFPA's country programme in Ethiopia 2017-2020, with the aim to strengthen access and quality of sexual and reproductive health and rights, and through an amendment to the agreement Sweden is planning to add funds for 2020 in order to scale up the contribution to the UNFPA:s response to Covid-19.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen är ett stöd till UNFPAs landprogram i Etiopien 2017-2020 för deras arbete med sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter, och genom avtalsändringen planerar Sverige att tillföra medel för att bidra till UNFPA:s respons på Covid-19 epedemin i Etiopien.

The objectives of the UNFPA country programme for Ethiopia 2016-2020 focus on: SRHR (including HIV), adolescents and youth, gender equality and women’s economic empowerment, and population dynamics. However, due to the spread of Covid-19 in Ethiopia, and the already noted and further expected negative consequences of the pandemic in terms of limiting access to SRHR, increasing GBV, and, placing a very heavy burden on the national health system, additional objectives for 2020 are included: -Ensuring continuity of access to SRHR services during the Covid-19 pandemic. -Addressing GBV, including strengthening health facilities and safe houses and access to them. -Ensuring a continuous supply of contraceptives and reproductive health services. -Promoting youth engagement for SRHR, and ‘leaving no one behind’. Promoting communication on risks due to Covid-19, and community engagement.

description.narrative: Overall this contribution has successfully assisted to ensure access to SRHR across the Ethiopian regions and to reach the most vulnerable in particular, especially youth and women, but also amongst IDPs and refugees. The contribution has also placed special emphasis on the continued access to SRHR under the pandemic, and the following important results were reported from UNFPA up to December 2020, as part of the Covid-19 response: training of 643 health workers trained on Maternal and Perinatal Death Surveillance and Reponse (MPDSR) and Emergency Bbstetric and Newborn Care (EmONC), 436 health workers trained on COVID-adapted SRHR services, 800 communities having made declarations against FGM/child marriage, 16 210 girls and boys survivors of GBV treated and got psychosocial and juridical support, and 4 733 women treated for fistula (116 treated January-June 2020).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: The Ethiopian Social Accountability Program phase I (ESAP I) was launched in 2006 by theGovernment of Ethiopia, with the support of International Development Partners as a part of theProtection of Basic Social Services (PBS). Hence the PBS program piloted Social Accountability (SA)that helped empower citizens to voice their needs and demands relating to essential public services.The SA, in the context of PBS, has been recognized as the processes by which ordinary citizens, whoare the users of public services, voice their needs, preferences, and demands regarding public services;it also brings citizens into dialogue with local governments and service providers to contribute toimproved quality public essential services through joint action plans. The PBS implemented by theGovernment of Ethiopia at regional, woreda, and kebele levels in collaboration with the developmentpartners manly the World Bank. The PBS has a nationwide scope and expresses the needs andconcerns of citizens regarding their access to education, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, andrural roads. While the program implemented through civil society organizations, it was possible toopen up channels of communication between citizens, responsible government bodies, and publicservice providers. A third programme phase, ESAP III, started in January 2019. The contribution is managed by the World Bank and implemented by a consultancy company called VNG (Dutch). According to the agreement with the World Bank the first narrative and financial report shall be submitted in 31 March 2020. This is however a continuation of a previous programme called ESAP II of which Sweden was part during a one year bridging phase (2018). Progress reports and an inception report for a planned review to be started in 2020, report the following start-up outputs for 2019: -All project agreements between the management agency (MA) of the Ethiopia Social Accountability Program (ESAP III) and its social accountability implementing partners (SAIPs) were finalized and fully executed. -The ESAP partners completed project team recruitment, complied with regional project appraisal requirements, signed project agreements with the regional Bureau of Finance and Economic Development (BoFED) and sectors, and started project implementation. Start-up activities included regional and woreda launching workshops, social mapping to identify vulnerable groups and developing strategies for their involvement in the SA process, sector selection with stakeholders, and the establishment or revival of SA committees (SACs). -SAIP M&E officers and gender and social inclusion (GSI) experts prepared their plans in consultation with the MA’s M&E and GSI teams. A more profound results reporting will according to the agreement be shared with donors in 2020.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: The Ethiopian Social Accountability Program phase I (ESAP I) was launched in 2006 by theGovernment of Ethiopia, with the support of International Development Partners as a part of theProtection of Basic Social Services (PBS). Hence the PBS program piloted Social Accountability (SA)that helped empower citizens to voice their needs and demands relating to essential public services.The SA, in the context of PBS, has been recognized as the processes by which ordinary citizens, whoare the users of public services, voice their needs, preferences, and demands regarding public services;it also brings citizens into dialogue with local governments and service providers to contribute toimproved quality public essential services through joint action plans. The PBS implemented by theGovernment of Ethiopia at regional, woreda, and kebele levels in collaboration with the developmentpartners manly the World Bank. The PBS has a nationwide scope and expresses the needs andconcerns of citizens regarding their access to education, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, andrural roads. While the program implemented through civil society organizations, it was possible toopen up channels of communication between citizens, responsible government bodies, and publicservice providers. A third programme phase, ESAP III, started in January 2019. The contribution is managed by the World Bank and implemented by a consultancy company called VNG (Dutch). According to the agreement with the World Bank the first narrative and financial report shall be submitted in 31 March 2020. This is however a continuation of a previous programme called ESAP II of which Sweden was part during a one year bridging phase (2018). Progress reports and an inception report for a planned review to be started in 2020, report the following start-up outputs for 2019: -All project agreements between the management agency (MA) of the Ethiopia Social Accountability Program (ESAP III) and its social accountability implementing partners (SAIPs) were finalized and fully executed. -The ESAP partners completed project team recruitment, complied with regional project appraisal requirements, signed project agreements with the regional Bureau of Finance and Economic Development (BoFED) and sectors, and started project implementation. Start-up activities included regional and woreda launching workshops, social mapping to identify vulnerable groups and developing strategies for their involvement in the SA process, sector selection with stakeholders, and the establishment or revival of SA committees (SACs). -SAIP M&E officers and gender and social inclusion (GSI) experts prepared their plans in consultation with the MA’s M&E and GSI teams. A more profound results reporting will according to the agreement be shared with donors in 2020.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
