tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.

4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: The O3 Zambia agreement was signed at the end of March 2019 and implementation started in April 2019. Reporting for 2019 was delayed since initially UNESCO reported the O3 Zambia results as a summary in the regional O3 report. Following dialogue UNESCO and the Embassy agreed that the two agreements although similar are different with different objectives, results frameworks, timelines, and contractual obligation. Therefore, a separate more detailed report was required in accordance to the agreement for the O3 Zambia. UNESCO thereafter worked on and submitted a separate detailed report for the O3 Zambia based on the results framework and annual work plan for the project. The following were key results for 2019. of learners reached by life - 2,121,145 Learners from grade 5 to 12 continued to receive life skills-based HIV and sexuality education - 5500 pre-service teachers out of a target of 5000 received training on CSE - 93 out of a target of 80 religious, traditional, and political leaders were sensitized on CSE and SRHR services for young people - 14 out of a target of 12 new CSE teaching and learning materials were produced, including ICT-based resources/products -
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Practical Action Green Economic Development 2017 - 2020
COVID-19 Practical Action Green Economic Development 2017 - 2020

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project will contribute to sustainable green economic growth in Zimbabwe by enhancing agricultural productivity with renewable energy and water efficient technologies, in Gwanda Rural District.
919 smallholder farming households (i.e. 4,135 men, women & children direct beneficiaries) will increase their incomes and yields by 100%, through participation in horticulture and other value chains.
The irrigation scheme beneficiary smallholders plus dryland farmers surrounding the irrigation schemes (a total of 919 smallholder farming households) – will increase crop production, have stronger performing Irrigation Management and Marketing Committees, better access to markets and finance, and increased resilience to climate change.
All residents of the wards (50,536 men, women and children) will benefit from better access to local food (doubling of yields on 319 hectares), inclusion of Livelihood Centred Disaster Risk Reduction (LCDRR) in ward plans, market development (opportunities for all producers, buyers and actors in selected value chains) and IWRM to conserve their resource base.
The project's technologies, approaches and businesses models will be shared nationally to promote investment/adoption by communities, government and other development agencies.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Practical Action har ansökt om finansiellt stöd från svenska ambassaden i Harare om 20 miljoner SEK med syfte att genomföra projektet "Enhanced Agricultural Productivity and Resilience to Climate Change through Solar Powered Irrigation” i Gwanda, Zimbabwe. Ambassaden kommer att stå som ensam givare i detta projekt.
Gwanda District har valts ut som fokusområde för denna insats på grund av följande skäl:
1) Gwanda District ligger i de agroekonomiska zonerna IV och V, vilket gör distriktet extremt sårbart för klimatvariation och klimatförändringar; 2) Distriktet har en stor population som till största del är beroende av jordbruk; 3) Gwanda District är för tillfället inte en del av Zimbabwe Resilience Builing Fund; 4) Distriktet har ett antal bevattningssystem som antingen är ur bruk eller drivna av diesel; 5) Matabeleland South har mottagit betydligt mindre bistånd i förhållande till andra provinser i Zimbabwe; 6) Practical Action har både erfarenhet och i dagsläget en närvaro i Gwanda.
Insatsen belyser de huvudsakliga orsakerna till fattigdom i Gwanda, så som låg jordbruksproduktivitet, brist på tillgång till ren och förnybar energi och småskaliga jordbruksbönders svaga organisatoriska förmåga. Även brist på kunskap och tillgång till rådgivning gällande jordbruket samt begränsad tillgång till marknaden och finansiella tjänster är faktorer som påverkar fattigdomen i Gwanda. Ett fokus för insatsen är att stärka jordbruksbönders anpassningsförmåga och motståndskraft för klimatvariationer och klimatförändringar.
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att öka jordbruksaktiviteten och motståndskraften för klimatförändringar inom Gwanda District genom soldrivna bevattningssystem samt ökad tillgång till marknaden och finansiella tjänster.
De huvudsakliga målen med insatsen är att:
1) På ett hållbart sätt öka växtproduktionen genom Participatory Extension Approaches (PEA) och Participatory Knowledge and Technology Developmnent.
2) Öka tillgången till marknader genom Participatory Market Systems Development (PMSD-metoder).
3) Öka tillgången till finansiella tjänster genom utveckling och stöd av 18 - 36 ISALs.
4) Öka motståndskraften mot klimatvariationer och klimatförändringar genom soldrivna bevattningssystem och bättre brukande av landområden. Dessa landområden, som beräknas stödja upp till 20 hushåll vardera, bevattnas genom vatten från borrhål som kommer att färdigställas under detta projekt. Insatsen avser dessutom stärka hushållens och samhällens motståndskraft genom att integrera Livelihood-Centred Disaster Risk Reduction (LCDRR).
5) Utveckla bevattningssystem genom Transformational Leadership Training, med syfte att förbättra lokalbefolkningens organisatoriska förmåga att äga och förvalta sina system.
Projektet kommer att bidra till en hållbar grön ekonomisk tillväxt i Zimbabwe genom att förbättra jordbruksproduktiviteten med hjälp av förnybar energi och vatteneffektiv teknik i Gwanda. Totalt kommer 919 småskaliga jordbrukshushåll (4.135 män, kvinnor och barn) att öka sina inkomster och avkastningar med 100% genom trädgårdsodling och andra värdekedjor.
Bevattningssystemets stödmottagare och bönder som brukar torra landområden (totalt 919 småhushållande jordbrukshushåll) - kommer att öka växtproduktionen. Dessutom kommer Irrigation Management and Marketing Committees stärkas och tillgången till marknader och finansiella tjänster samt öka motståndskraften mot klimatförändringar kommer att förbättras.
Alla invånare i distriktet (50.536 män, kvinnor och barn) kommer att dra nytta av bättre tillgång till lokalproducerad mat (fördubbling av avkastning på 319 hektar), Livelihood-Centred Disaster Risk Reduction (LCDRR), en utveckling av marknaden (möjligheter för alla producenter, köpare och aktörer i utvalda värdekedjor) samt IWRM.
Projektets teknologier, metoder och affärsmodeller kommer att delas nationellt med syfte att främja investeringar gjorda av samhällena, myndigheter och andra aktörer inom utvecklingssektorn.
Ambassaden bedömer att den föreslagna insatsen uppfyller ett flertal resultat i strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete med Zimbabwe 2017-2021. Insatsen fokuserar främst på klimatförändringar med målet att skapa mer motståndskraftiga hushåll och individer (resultatområde 3.1) och integrera användningen av produktiv förnybar energi i form av soldrivna bevattningssystem (resultatområde 3.3). Genom betoningen på värdekedjemetoder och kopplingar till marknader och finanser avser insatsen skapa gröna och motståndskraftiga jobb och inkomster för några av de mest utsatta samhällena i Zimbabwe (resultatområde 3.2). Dessutom har insatsen genomgående ett genusperspektiv (område 1.3) och en konfliktkänslighet vilket är särskilt viktigt med tanke på de konflikter som pågick i Gwanda under 1980- och 2000-talen.
Insatsen relaterar direkt till följande av FNs globala mål för en hållbar utveckling:
1) Ingen fattigdom 2) Ingen hunger 5) Jämställdhet 6) Rent vatten och sanitet 7) Hållbar energi för alla 9) Hållbar industri, innovationer och infrastruktur 13) Bekämpa klimatförändringen

tag.narrative: 13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

description.narrative: Installation of solar irrigation at Silikwe has been completed and farmers began planting in August 2019. Drip irrigation has been extremely successful in half of the irrigation area and farmers are growing tomatoes for an already secured market through the marketing committees that have been established in the project. Installation of solar irrigation at Sukwi Irrigation Scheme is at 94% and is due to be cmpleted by the end of November. In the Silikwe (Gwanda North) cluster, progress with drilling is now at 63% with 5 out of the targeted 8 boreholes successfully drilled. In the Sukwi (Gwanda South) cluster progress with borehole drilling is now at 43% with 3 of the targeted 7 boreholes successfully drilled. 100% of farmers have reported accessing improved extension services. 98% of farmers are now able to access improved markets, through the 7 marketing committees that have been set up by the project. Number of ISAL groups has been significantly exceeded with 23 groups being formed across the programme site, with average monthly earnings doubling for beneficiary farmers. The number of women elected to and actively engaged in leadership positions in the irrigation management committees has been exceeded my 104%. Training on the following have been conducted in all sites: - Value Chain Selection - Gender sensitization - ISAL Training - Financial literacy - Climate Change Awareness - Operation and Management of Irrigation Equipment - Irrigation Scheduling - Using Climate Data and Information
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sveriges ambassad har fått en ansökan från UNDP BIH om stöd med 39 MSEK för att genomföra projektet GED “Green Economic Programme - Fas 2" i Bosnien och Hercegovina (BIH) under perioden 2018-2020.
Syfte med projektet är att förbättra och öka energieffektiviteten i BiH som kan uppnås genom att genomföra sex sammankopplade och kompletterande komponenter: 1) Kapacitetsuppbyggnad och rättsliga ramar för energieffektivisering och förnybar energi. Utveckling och kapacitetsuppbyggnad av kommuner, miljöfonder och energipersonal inom energieffektiva offentliga belysningssystem, förnybara energikällor och utvecklingsfördelar av EE/RES projekt. 2) Institutionalisering av energihantering - kostnader, utsläppshantering och övervakning av växthusgaser i BiH kommuner (GED projektet täckte endast entiteternas och kantonnivåen). 3) Utveckling av finansiella mekanismer för grön ekonomisk finansiering i Bosnien och Hercegovina - Utveckling och antagande av hållbara finansiella mekanismer inom fonderna för miljöskydd inom energieffektivitet och förnybara energikällor som bygger, bidrar till och kontrollerar miljö och mänsklig utveckling. 4) Infrastrukturåtgärder i kommuner i Bosnien och Hercegovina - energieffektiva offentliga belysningssystem; solsystem i offentliga byggnader; energieffektivitet och förnybara energiåtgärder i offentliga byggnader 5) medvetenhet och marknadsföringskampanj till allmänheten - öka allmänhetens medvetande om utveckling som en följd av ren och förnybar energi och energieffektivitet. 6) Förnybara energilösningar för hushåll på landsbygden utanför elnätet - tillhandahålla lösningar för solceller och solsystem (el och värmeproduktion) till avlägsna områden (ej anslutna till elnätet) utan el i BiH.
Projektet är en fortsättning av GED (Green Economic Development) som genomförs av UNDP och finansieras av Sverige sedan år 2014 som kommer att avslutas i 2018. Projektet har uppnått bra resultat och många av målen har t.o.m. överstigit.
Total budget för projektet är 55 MSEK, varav miljöskyddsfonderna och UNDP ska bidra med cirka 15 MSEK och Sveriges ambassad ska finansiera med 39 MSEK under perioden 2018-2020. 1 MSEK ska sättas undan inom en separat komponent för uppföljning och utvärdering.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNDP BIH has approached Embassy of Sweden/Sida for funding of 39 million SEK to carry out the “Green Economic Programme - Phase 2” in Bosna and Herzegovina during the period 2018-2020. The intervention aims at improving and scale up of energy efficiency in BIH which will be achieved by implementation of six interlinked and supplementary project components:: 1) Capacity Building & Legal Framework for EE/RES– Development and capacity building of municipal authorities, Environmental Funds and energy professionals on energy efficient public lighting systems and renewable energy sources and human development benefits of EE/RES projects. 2) Institutionalization of energy management– Systematic energy, costs and GHG emission management and monitoring in BiH municipalities (the GED project previously covered the entity and cantonal level only). 3) Development of financial mechanisms for green economic financing in BiH – Development and adoption of sustainable financial mechanisms within Environmental Protection Funds on energy efficiency and renewable energy sources which are based, contribute and capture/monitor environmental and human development. 4) Infrastructure measures in BiH municipalities - energy efficient public lighting systems; solar systems at public sector buildings; infrastructural energy efficiency and renewable energy measures in public sector buildings 5) Public awareness / marketing campaign– increasing public awareness on human development as a result of clean/renewable energy and on energy efficiency. 6) Renewable energy solution for households living in rural areas off the power grid – provide hybrid phot
The intervention presents logical continuation to the ongoing Green Economic Development (GED) Project, implemented by UNDP and financed by Sweden since 2014, which is coming to its end after 2018. but which has achieved many good results and exceeded a lot of targets.
The intervention’s total budget is 55 million SEK, out of which two environmental funds and UNDP are contributing with approximately 30 million SEK and 39MSEK is Swedens contribution for the period 2018-2020. Additionally, 1 MSEK will be reserved within separate component for monitoring and evaluation purposes.

The main goal of Green Economic Development phase II project is to further contribute to scale up of energy efficiency in BIH and the creation of a favourable environment for investing in EE and RES measures in BiH.

tag.narrative: 1.1 - By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.
1.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa den extrema fattigdomen för alla människor överallt. Med extrem fattigdom avses för närvarande människor som lever på mindre än 1,25 US-dollar per dag.
11.3 - By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.
11.3 - Till 2030 verka för en inkluderande och hållbar urbanisering samt förbättra kapaciteten för deltagandebaserad, integrerad och hållbar planering och förvaltning av bosättningar i alla länder.

13.a - Fullfölja det åtagande som de utvecklade länder som är parter i Förenta nationernas ramkonvention om klimatförändringar gjort gällande en målsättning att till 2020 gemensamt mobilisera 100 miljarder US-dollar årligen från alla typer av källor för att tillgodose utvecklingsländernas behov vad gäller meningsfulla begränsningsåtgärder och insyn i genomförandet samt så snart som möjligt finansiera och operationalisera den gröna klimatfonden fullt ut.

13.a - Implement the commitment undertaken by developed-country parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change to a goal of mobilizing jointly $100 billion annually by 2020 from all sources to address the needs of developing countries in the context of meaningful mitigation actions and transparency on implementation and fully operationalize the Green Climate Fund through its capitalization as soon as possible.
3.d - Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.
3.d - Stärka alla länders, i synnerhet utvecklingsländernas, kapacitet när det gäller tidig varning, riskreducering och hantering av nationella och globala hälsorisker.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt

7.b - By 2030, expand infrastructure and upgrade technology for supplying modern and sustainable energy services for all in developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and landlocked developing countries, in accordance with their respective programmes of support.

7.b - Till 2030 bygga ut infrastrukturen och uppgradera tekniken för att leverera moderna och hållbara energitjänster till alla i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna och små önationer under utveckling.
8.9 - By 2030, devise and implement policies to promote sustainable tourism that creates jobs and promotes local culture and products.
8.9 - Senast 2030 utarbeta och genomföra politik för hållbar turism som skapar arbetstillfällen och främjar lokal kultur och lokala produkter.

9.1 - Bygga ut tillförlitlig, hållbar och motståndskraftig infrastruktur av hög kvalitet, inklusive regional och gränsöverskridande infrastruktur, för att stödja ekonomisk utveckling och människors välbefinnande, med fokus på ekonomiskt överkomlig och rättvis tillgång för alla.

9.1 - Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.

title.narrative: Decision on amendment 3 to the agreement

description.narrative: Project continues with a good progress on all components. Overview of achievements in 2019 and related challenges is presented below: The project is continuing with scaling-up and creation self-sustainability within EE/RES related activities in BiH and contribution to BiH‘s EU accession and fulfilment of Energy Community Treaty obligations. “Rulebook on Energy Efficiency Information System for FBiH” (ISEE, http://www.iseefbih.ba/) has been adopted in January 2019, and “Decision on the establishment of energy management system and information system of energy efficiency in institutions at the state level BiH and mandatory data entry and regular reporting” has been adopted by Council of Ministers of BIH in June 2019, which positioned EMIS for the first time as obligatory software for monitoring and reporting regarding energy consumption in public sector in BiH. The Rulebook for Republika Srpska is prepared, but not adopted yet. The organizational scheme for energy management system at the state level of BiH is developed, and it implies appointment of one energy manager-coordinator and one energy manager in Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Relations of BiH and one energy manager in the Service for Common Affairs of the Institutions of BiH, which are going to be the carriers of activities in establishment of energy management system. Mentioned energy managers were employed through the Project for the period of 18 months, while after this period they will be employed by mentioned institutions. These activities, together with installation of energy monitoring equipment for each building used by state government institutions of BiH, will ensure a self-sustainability. The Energy Intensity Mapping application has been developed as a new module within the EMIS. The tool provides an easy visualization of the energy intensity in buildings through a virtual and interactive map with a user-friendly interface. It is a unique database that combines energy consumption (kWh) and building characteristics (m2 of heated area, building type, number of beneficiaries). The map enables a comparison of energy or water consumption, as well as CO2 emissions over time for any given building, or group of buildings, which also facilitates the tracking of savings for buildings that have been retrofitted. The tool is also equipped with the spreadsheets which can be exported for analytical or other purposes. Infrastructure works were performed on 47 public buildings. Solar systems have been installed on 10 buildings, and 6 public lighting systems have been modernized with new, energy-efficient LED luminaires. By implementing energy efficiency infrastructural works and taking into account prices and real energy needs baseline, most of the buildings will achieve about 50% of cost savings, and total amount of CO2 emission reduction is 2,624 t. Number of direct beneficiaries of energy efficiency/renewable energy sources infrastructural works is 452,084, out of which 207,958 women. Since the total investment for conducted works in 2019 is 10,598,955.77 BAM, the total number of generated “green jobs” is 518. Swedish funds helped to unlock available funds for energy efficiency measures from end users (owners of public institutions), and total ratio of co-financing is 70% by local institutions and 30% grant. Owners of buildings committed to re-invest energy savings into further retrofitting of their buildings or other infrastructure. The installation of solar systems for the off grid households without access to electricity was implemented for 16 households with a total of 52 users, of which 55.7% were men and 44.3% women. Air quality measuring equipment, which by its characteristics belongs to the group of the most modern devices currently available in the world when it comes to measuring air pollution parameters, was purchased for the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering in Sarajevo, and it will significantly contribute to the research projects related to improvement of the air quality in Sarajevo Canton. Synergies have been continuously established with other internationally financed EEproject, primarily with World bank financed project, GIZ and USAID. The UNDP is a key partner of the Programme holding entire responsibility for theimplementation, whilst two entities’ environmental funds and number of cantonal andmunicipal authorities are important programme partners and co-financiers of theprogramme. Cooperation with UNDP was very good and productive duringthe implementation period. Progress was discussed bi-annually at regular project board meetings, among representatives of UNDP, both environmental funds, MOFTER and the Embassy. Results were regularly reported through annual reports, but also regularly through daily communication or based on ad-hock requests. All deliveries were timely and of sufficient quality. Finally, the project has been effective during reporting period, achieving many positive results under each component.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektet kommer stärka efterfrågan på arbetskraft genom riktade åtgärder för att förbättra anställningsbarheten av arbetskraften, särskilt unga, kvinnor och lågutbildade, genom att samarbeta med privata arbetsförmedlare. Projektet är en del av det större programmet World Bank Employment Support Development Policy Loan värt $50 miljoner. Projektet kommer att implementeras av Världsbanken genom fonderade medel förmedlade av VB (Bank Executed Trust Funds). Projektet finansieras med 23 miljoner SEK under 3 år, 100 % finansierat av Sida.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project will strengthen labor demand by targeted measures to improve the employability of workforce (particularly youths, women, low skilled) through engaging with private job brokerages (employment service providers) The project is part of a larger programme: World Bank Employment Support Development Policy Loan in the amount of $50 million. The project will be implemented by the World Bank using bank executed trust fund modality. The project is 23MSEK over three years, 100% supported by Sida.

description.narrative: The Conclusion on Performance is made on basis of second annual report received from the World in July 2020. The target group of the intervention are the long term unemployed in the BiH laborforce, with particular focus on women and youth. An amendment (no cost) was made to include COVID 19 related job losses as well. The project partners with the public employment services with an impact objective of improving the outreach of their programs (wage subsidies mostly) that World Bank estimates reach less than 5% of registered jobseekers. The World Bank is managing the project in sequence of three steps. During the first year, a contract was awarded to Deloitte to make a diagnostic of selected companies (small and medium size private companies) in order to determine main obstacles and needs for increasing labor demand. This work was completed during year 1 of the project. During the 2nd and 3rd year, the World Bank will, through a contract awarded to Kolektiv doo, a private employment agency, pilot a package of services to jobseekers that will improve their ability to find and hold jobs (initially the idea was that the jobseekers will be taken from official lists) Kolektiv will be paid a fixed price per beneficiary placed in a job. The aim of the pilot is to encourage provision of an optimal set of personalized services in the most cost effective way. The beneficiaries will have the same characteristics as those served through the public system. The project will target 2500 through a public call (instead of pool of registered due to limitations with protection of personal data legislation) At least half will be women, low skilled and long term unemployed. Finally the World Bank at the end of the project will make an evaluation of the Kolektiv pilot which will support the overall development objective of the project which is to inform policy making on the impact of the private provision of employment services. Due to the COVID situation, the project had to adjust. A 12 month no cost extension (the WB did not ask for additional funds) was agreed in June, and the number of target beneficiaries expanded from 2000 to 2500. A call was published by Kolektiv doo in August covering two cantons (Sarajevo and HN Canton) For the time being, according to the WB, the call will be limited to those two cantons. It is assessed that there will be a huge demand from the call.The report also contains an updated risk analysis which is assessed to contain accurate risks. The report is also made on the financial situation. It is showing actual and commitments of 1,2MUSD cumulative against a revised budget of 2.69MUSD. This is in line with progress on activities. The controller has seen the financial statement and issued no comment.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Overview of the LFA and annual report: The LFA gives a quantifiable basis for monitoring all of the success indicators. The narrative report goes into detail on the successes. The baseline indicators are selected from the LFA below: Output 1.1. Passive youth mobilized and influence Target: 45 initiatives implemented in 45 local communities 2020+2019: 13 initiatives implemented in 12 local communities This indicator has not been performing as ambitiously as it was planned. KULT could have done more on the outreach. If there are limited quality applications, then perhaps some capacity building is necessary. Target: 75 youth leaders from 75 communities gain skills (both programs UMID and UMIDp) 2020+2019: Over 50 youth leaders and youth political leaders from over 50 local communities gained skills On the other had this indicator has been ambitiously implemented. Output 1.2 Local stakeholders greater respect for human rights Target 15 political initiatives implemented in at least 10 communities 2020+2019: 11 different local communities started off with political initiative on law on youth implementation Target: 75 young politicians gained skills, 50 youth officers gain skills 2020: 50 young politicians graduate and 93 youth officers graduate The narrative report highlights the following: Training participants (youth officers and youth activists) continue to come from all parts of BiH. In 2020 cycle of training: out of 56 applications 26 were selected (16 women, 10 men) from 19 communities. Most come from Federation BiH, with three from RS. The training for politicians is also reported by KULT as successful. At the impact level, during 2020, it is reported that 12 graduated trainees from the young politicians program were elected into local council and one participant was elected mayor. One of the participants was appointed Advisor on Civil Society in the Brcko District. At the output levels there were a total of 28 applications for the politicians programme in 2020. 23 participants from 8 political parties (SDA, DF, NiP, NS, HDZ, SNSD, etc) took part in the training, 6 of which were female. 8 of the 12 graduates were in the top 8 (very high on their party's lists) Alumni of UMID programs participants is key to future program sustainability (promotes networks and bonds between participants) The programs, "even without forefronting reconciliation, are building trust and allowing for connections between individuals and institutions, thus creating a climate where sustainable peace can flourish" The Entrepreneurial Fund for Youth is KULT's model of institutional establishment of support programs for young entrepreneurs and innovators in local communities in order to strengthen the economy in BiH and develop youth entrepreneurship. 40 businesses in 8 communities have been supported through Swedish support. During 2020 the focus was on monitoring and promotion of successful business as well as capacity building for municipalities in supporting youth to launch their businesses. Enteprenuership fund and the youth politician training component could include more women. KULT is needing to develop more gender transformative indicators and not only track gender disaggregated statistics. KULT has been working on Implementation of the Law on Volunteering, but mostly within the context of its public awareness component. This work has been limited to the Federation BiH. During 2020 KULT tested new online system for grant applications. It is designed to be interactive and can provide valuable feedback to KULT so as to improve the application process for future applicants. Conclusion of annual review meeting discussion (from Minutes of Meeting): -It would be beneficial if Embassy team can get more info how project implementation supported KULT internal development KULT is seen and understood as strategic partner to youth in BiH and strategic partner to Embassy for youth issues in BiH. -It would be beneficial for Embassy to understand better how both entities (FBiH and RS) and District Brcko are included in project, which components and how KULT makes bridges between youth across entities. -KULT can consider how to use experience and influence and effects of Covid-19 adjustments to future organizational and activity development, e.g. how current digitalization of specific components and activities can be used in future to boost up project results and still keep quality of work with beneficiaries (youth, youth organizations and decision makers). This means that KULT could use online tools for support to measures and aims that want to achieve. The project team stated that digitalization does not mean necessary substitution of methods but rather support to current in person activities. -It is necessary to understand more clear how Entrepreneurial component of the project is connected and supporting other components, thus supporting youth issues development and democratization of the BiH society. This component can have different activities in future to more support local (municipal) decision makers and bridge entrepreneurship funds to youth policy development. -Impact of education for youth political leaders is beneficial for different local and wider society process in BiH -Promotion of good practices and successful individual stories can support development of creation of critical mass of youth in BiH. More networking to other programs can be beneficial to future project implementation -Joint efforts of the Embassy and KULT toward decision makers can be supportive in change-making process and shifting the mindset
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Conclusion of annual review meeting discussion (from Minutes of Meeting): -It would be beneficial if Embassy team can get more info how project implementation supported KULT internal development KULT is seen and understood as strategic partner to youth in BiH and strategic partner to Embassy for youth issues in BiH. -It would be beneficial for Embassy to understand better how both entities (FBiH and RS) and District Brcko are included in project, which components and how KULT makes bridges between youth across entities. -KULT can consider how to use experience and influence and effects of Covid-19 adjustments to future organizational and activity development, e.g. how current digitalization of specific components and activities can be used in future to boost up project results and still keep quality of work with beneficiaries (youth, youth organizations and decision makers). This means that KULT could use online tools for support to measures and aims that want to achieve. The project team stated that digitalization does not mean necessary substitution of methods but rather support to current in person activities. -It is necessary to understand more clear how Entrepreneurial component of the project is connected and supporting other components, thus supporting youth issues development and democratization of the BiH society. This component can have different activities in future to more support local (municipal) decision makers and bridge entrepreneurship funds to youth policy development. -Impact of education for youth political leaders is beneficial for different local and wider society process in BiH -Promotion of good practices and successful individual stories can support development of creation of critical mass of youth in BiH. More networking to other programs can be beneficial to future project implementation -Joint efforts of the Embassy and KULT toward decision makers can be supportive in change-making process and shifting the mindset
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Consolidate Gains & Deepen Devolution UNDP
COVID-19 Konsolidera framgångar och fördjupa devolution UNDP

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Sverige stöder den kenyanska regeringens och FN:s program Consolidating Gains and Deepening Devolution in Kenya (Konsolidera framgångar och fördjupa devolutionen i Kenya) med SEK 75 miljoner. Devolution är en viss typ av decentralisering: den lagstadgade delegeringen av befogenheter från centralregeringen till regeringen på subnationell nivå – i detta fall länsnivå.
Målet med programmet är att människor i Kenya får tillgång till högkvalitativa tjänster på devolverad nivå som är välkoordinerade, integrerade, transparenta, rättvist finansierade och redovisningsskyldiga fram till 2022, och därmed bidra till ett demokratiskt politiskt system som är frågeställningsbaserat, resultatinriktat och redovisningsskyldiga till allmänheten. Detta kommer att uppnås genom att 1) stärka politiska, rättsliga och institutionella mekanismer för samordnad, inkluderande och effektiv tjänsteleverans, 2) utveckla institutioner för offentliga finanser med stärkta processer och system för rättvis, effektiv och ansvarsfull leverans av tjänster; 3) utveckla länsinstitutionernas kapacitet för evidensbaserad planering, budgetering, genomförande, övervakning och utvärdering för ansvarsfull service och 4) utveckla förmågan hos människor i Kenya att engagera sig, fördjupa ansvarsskyldighet och öppenhet i devolution, särskilt kvinnor, ungdomar och personer med funktionshinder
Programmet är inriktat på 14 av de 47 länen, valda på grund av kriterier som fattigdom, torrhet, ojämlikhet mellan kön, barnfattigdom, katastrofrisk och problem över gränserna.
Programmet kommer att förvaltas av UNDP och genomföras av UNDP, UNICEF, UN Women, Kenyas regering och andra.
“Consolidating Gains and Deepening Devolution in Kenya,” Gemensamt programdokument, slutversion (Republic of Kenya och United Nations Kenya [25 juni 2019])

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Sweden is supporting the Government of Kenya/UN program Consolidating Gains and Deepening Devolution in Kenya with SEK 75 million. Devolution is a certain kind of decentralization: the statutory delegation of powers from the central government to government at the subnational – in this case county – level.
The goal of the program is that people in Kenya access high quality services at devolved level that are well coordinated, integrated, transparent, equitably resourced and accountable by 2022, thereby contributing to a democratic political system that is issue-based, results-oriented and accountable to the public. This will be attained by 1) strengthening policy, legal and institutional mechanisms for coordinated, inclusive and effective service delivery; 2) developing public finance management institutions with strengthened processes and systems for equitable, efficient and accountable service delivery; 3) developing county-level institutions’ capacity for evidence-based planning, budgeting, implementation, monitoring and evaluation for accountable service delivery; and 4) developing the capacity of people in Kenya to engage, deepen accountability and transparency in devolution, especially women, youth and persons with disability.
The program is focused on 14 of the 47 counties, chosen on the basis of criteria such as poverty, aridness, gender inequality, child deprivation, disaster risk, and cross-border issues.
The program will be managed by UNDP and implemented by UNDP, UNICEF, UN Women, the Government of Kenya, and others.
“Consolidating Gains and Deepening Devolution in Kenya,” Joint Programme Document, final version (Republic of Kenya and United Nations Kenya [25 June 2019])

The goals of the UNDP devolution program are as follows: *Impact: A democratic political system that is issue-based, results-oriented and accountable to the public. (Government of Kenya Medium Term Plan III Result) *Outcome 1: By 2022 people in Kenya access high quality services at devolved level that are well coordinated, integrated, transparent, equitably resourced and accountable. (UNDAF outcome 1.2.) *Output 1.1: Government has strengthened policy, legal and institutional mechanisms for coordinated, inclusive and effective service delivery *Output 1.2: Public finance management institutions have strengthened processes and systems for equitable, efficient and accountable service delivery *Output 1.3: County level institutions have strengthened capacity for evidence-based planning, budgeting, implementation, monitoring and evaluation for accountable service delivery *Output 1.4: People in Kenya have capacity to engage, deepen accountability and transparency in devolution, especially women, youth and persons with disability

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

title.narrative: Decision Konsolidera Framgångar och Fördjupa Devolution UNDP

description.narrative: Context: County governments in Kenya were established in 2013. Sweden, Denmark and Italy support a program to strengthen the counties, which is implemented by UNDP, UNICEF and UN Women together with government ministries, agencies 14 of the poorer counties’ governments, the private sector and civil society. The program is broad and diverse. Moreover, in March-September 2020, it was agreed that the program would implement additional measures to deal with the COVID-19 emergency. Generally the program has been implemented close to plan, despite the difficulties caused by the pandemic. Output 1.1: Government has strengthened policy, legal and institutional mechanisms for coordinated, inclusive and effective service delivery *The Inter-Governmental Relations Technical Committee developed key reference material for counties and the national government on the implementation of devolved governance in Kenya. *Four county governments developed plans to implement achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. *The Frontier Counties Development Council Regional Economic Bloc was established. *The draft Model County Gender Policy stimulated review of the current status of gender balance in the counties based on the findings of the gender audit conducted in 2018. *The programme developed and rolled out public finance management frameworks and followed up on policy issues affecting planning and budgeting for children, youth and women. Fourteen child protection working groups (one per programme county) were established to plan and implement various child protection interventions and strategies. *The programme developed county budget briefs with recommendations on the inclusion of women, children and youth priorities in county budget work. All 47 counties included some key recommendations in their 2020/2021 budgets. *The programme developed a guide for county governments on care for children in the streets and residential care. Three counties are using the guide to implement alternative care programmes. *The programme helped finalize the guidelines for County Annual Development Plans and three counties finalized their plans. *The programme helped develop subsidiary legislation on the County Governments Act 2012 and the Intergovernmental Relations Act 2012, which should enhance county service delivery and strengthen intergovernmental relations. Output 1.2: Public finance management institutions have strengthened processes and systems for equitable, efficient and accountable service delivery *All the 47 county governments formed County Budget and Economic Forums, where representatives for civil society and underrepresented groups could discuss county budget issues. These forums were involved in the budgeting process to varying degrees in different counties. *The Controller of Budget commenced the automation of a budget reporting system, which will accelerate the release of funds to spending units and enable more analytical and enhance accountability and public access to finance information. *Counties may generate “own source revenue” from property rates, entertainment taxes, levies, user fees and other charges. Seven joint programme counties were among the 13 counties nationally that recorded increase in Own Source Revenue in FY 19/20, despite COVID-19 challenges. *The programme supported a new standard chart of accounts for use by county governments in the planning/budgeting process. The standard was finalized and is awaiting approval by the Cabinet and roll-out. *The programme helped undertake a Tax Administration Diagnostic Assessment of three counties, which can improve own source income in these counties. Output 1.3: County level institutions have strengthened capacity for evidence-based planning, budgeting, implementation, monitoring and evaluation for accountable service delivery *At the beginning of the previous devolution programme in 2014/2015, none of the focus counites had a performance management system. During the past year, nine counties signed performance contracts for 2020/21 financial years, and three more are in advanced stage of signing the Performance Contracts. *The programme enhanced adoption of county integrated monitoring and evaluation system in one program county. The programme also worked with Kenya National Bureau of Statistics to produce county inequality and employment reports, to plan initiatives for social inclusion and employment. An analysis of inequality in Kenya is on-going. *The programme supported regular infographics for on-going emergencies (COVID-19, floods, food insecurity and refugee crisis) for 14 arid and semi-arid counties, improving disaster risk management. The programme also supported development of county disaster risk profiles in 11 counties. Output 1.4: People in Kenya have capacity to engage, deepen accountability and transparency in devolution, especially women, youth and persons with disability *The programme improved the publicizing of seven county budget documents. *The programme provided developing the capacity and networking of 89 youth and women agribusiness small and micro enterprises. Thirty-two companies j0ined the Women Empowerment Programmes to support women growing their businesses. Joint Devolution Programme Support to COVID-19 Response *The programme improved public awareness of COVID-19, reaching over 99% of the population. The programme deployed 17 tele-counsellors to provide psychosocial support to vulnerable groups. The programme reached more than 20 million people through TV, 23 million people through local-language radios and 202,050 people through SMS text messages with targeted messaging on COVID-19. Through Hotline 1195, 2,601 survivors of gender-based violence were connected to access essential services. *The programme procured and distributed 9,898 full Personnel Protective Equipment (PPE) kits, 3,038 face masks, 490 bottles of sanitizers and 3,626 packets of gloves to 14 counties. *The programme facilitated cash transfers to 3,000 urban vulnerable households and 5,800 poor households in five counties. *The programme deployed 50 UN volunteers to work in 14 counties as COVID-19 responders. This resulted in mass testing of 214,550 people, COVID-19 surveillance in 70 wards, and care of 3,500 patients in isolation centres, among other things. *The programme provided technical assistance to develop a strategy to help counties to build back better, strengthen their crisis and disaster response, and revitalize economies following the pandemic. *The programme strengthened participation of women, youth, and people with disabilities in County Emergency Response Committees from 14 counties. The programme supported the government in implementing a national COVID-19 recovery framework. Source: The annual report, UNDP, UN Women and UNICEF, “Consolidating Gains and Deepening Devolution in Kenya: Programme Annual Progress Report: January 1 – December 31, 2020,” was submitted on March 30, 2021.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen syftar till att minska mäns våld mot kvinnor och främja jämställdhetsarbetet i Belarus genom att engagera män i pappagrupper samt skapa stödsystem för män som är beredda att reflektera kring maskulinitet samt riktade aktiviteter mot unga i syfte att utmana destruktiva mansnormer.
Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The contributio aims at engaging men for gender equality in Belarus, as well as ending men's violence against women.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Hämtade från överlämning november 2019:Under år 2018 har en mängd aktiviteter genomförts och flera viktiga resultat haruppnåtts. Detta trots att den ena samarbetspartnern, Gender Perspectives (GP) inte ficksin del av projektet registrerad. Detta har inneburit att flera aktiviteter inte har kunnatgenomföras som planerat och därmed har skjutits på framtiden. Detta gäller bland annatförebyggande arbete riktat mot ungdomar. GP har dock kunnat medverka i relativ höggrad inom ramen för den andra delen av projektet, som huvudsakligen hanteras av KlubLvov. Deras roll är viktig för att säkerställa projektets "accountability" gentemotkvinnorörelsen och för att koppla ihop projektets aktiviteter med det övergripandejämställdhetsarbetet i Vitryssland. Glädjande nog kom besked i september 2019 attprojektet äntligen hade blivit registrerat, och därmed kommer aktiviteterna som GenderPerspectives ansvarar för att kunna startas upp.Ett viktigt resultat under året var att det nationella parlamentet planerade att anta en nyarbetsmarknadslagstiftning som innefattar obligatorisk pappaledighet. Vid tidpunkten förrapporten skulle den nya lagen antas av representanthuset. Arbetet med att utvecklalagstiftning mot våld i hemmet, stötte däremot på patrull. Flera religiösa organisationerprotesterade mot förslaget och då presidenten uttalade sig kritiskt stoppades arbetet medden nya lagen. En fortsatt diskussion om vikten av lagstifnting på området fortsätter dockatt föras, och här har särskilt GP en aktiv roll.Ett mycket viktigt resultat av arbetet är att Klub Lvov har skrivit ett avtal med"territoriella center" för staden Minsk och landets regioner för att ta fram ett organiseratsystem för att hålla pappagruppsmöten på mer permanent basis. Detta kommer även attunderlätta genomförandet av projektet under kommande år.Klub Lvovs arbete med pappagrupper har också som planerat expanderat geografisktoch 14 nya moderatorer har tränats för att hålla pappagrupper i olika delar av landet,varav tre i Mogilev, 4 i Vitebsk, 2 i Borisov, 2 i Molodechno, 1 i Marina Gorka och 2 iDerzhinsk.Media har också visat intresse för projektet och detta har bidragit till att stärkadiskussionen om jämställda familjer och ansvarsfullt faderskap.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2021
strategy.titleSV: Reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet 2014-2021

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 The International Development Law Organisation (IDLO) har inkommit med en ansökan om 30 MSEK för att stödja ett projekt med syfte att öka de kenyanska medborgarnas tillgång till rättssystemet/rättvisa, öka transparens och ansvarsutkrävande på både nationell och länsnivå, enligt Kenyas grundlag från 2010. Insatsen kommer att stödja nyckelinstitutioner inom rättsväsendet för att genomföra den strategiska planen och styrdokumentet "Sustaining Judiciary Transformation" (SJT). Projektet kommer även att stödja det 'nationella rådet för rättsskipning' (National Council on Administration of Justice, NCAJ), där bl.a. aktörer inom straffrätten ingår, i dess reformer mot större öppenhet och ansvarsutkrävande från medborgarna. Rättshjälp (legal aid) är en annan viktig komponent i projektet som kommer stödja implementeringen av den lag från 2016 som ska säkra att även utsatta människor får tillgång till rättshjälp. Projektet kommer även att arbeta med civilsamhällesorganisationer och grundlagskommissioner vad gäller öppenhet och ansvarsutkrävande, inklusive mekanismer för allmänheten att framföra klagomål mot nationella och lokala myndigheter. Viktiga aktörer som den kenyanska riksrevisionen, antikorruptionskommissionen, justitiedepartementet, guvernörsrådet (Council of Governors), finansdepartementet och parlamentets budgetkontor kommer att stödjas i arbetet med att ta fram policydokument och efterlevnad

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The International Development Law Organisation (IDLO) has submitted a proposal of 30 MSEK to support a project aiming to increase access to justice for the Kenyan citizens, increase transparency and accountability on national and county levels, in line with the 2010 Constitution of Kenya. The contribution will support key institutions within the justice sector to implement their Strategic Plan as well as the blueprint " Sustaining Judiciary Transformation" (SJT). The project will also support the National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ), including actors within the criminal justic chain, with the ongoing implementation of reforms. Legal aid is another substantial component in the project, and the implementation of the 2016 Legal Aid Act aiming to secure legal aid to vulnerable people, will receive support. The project will also support CSOs and Constitutional Commissions in terms of transparency and accountability, including public complaints handling mechanisms. Important actors such as the Office of the Auditor General; Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission, the OAG/DOJ, the Council of Governors, the National Treasury and the Parliamentary Budget Office will be supported in developing of policies and compliance.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

description.narrative: In the last six months, IDLO focused on strengthening institutional capacity of the Judiciary, the National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ) and other relevant justice sector actors, improve access to justice through reduction of case backlog; enhanced quality of legal frameworks for access to justice, improved linkages between formal and informal justice systems; and improved coordination of justice actors under the NCAJ leadership. The follwoing are some of the results that have been realised: 1. Enhanced access to justice through reduced case backlog in the Court of Appeal: IDLO supported reduction of the backlog in the Court of Appeal (COA) through support to service weeks and circuit visits to court stations where the COA does not ordinarily sit. The planned service week in March for the Kisumu Law courts was disrupted by theGovernment directive for nationwide lockdown. This did not affect the matters that had been set for hearing, as all the 62 matters scheduled for hearing were heard and determined through video-conferencing. From April 2020, COA hearings were virtual. As of June 2020, 219 appeal cases have been heard and determined and 213 rulings/ judgements delivered. Virtual hearings have ensured reduction of appeal case backlog and continuity of administration of justice during the pandemic. 2. Enhanced access to information on ongoing automation of judicial processes: Due to the effects of COVID-19 and the need to address emerging justice needs, IDLO supported the Judiciary’s Directorate of Public Affairs and Communications (DPAC) to run media public announcements and television infomercials in June 2020. The infomercials provided information to citizens on how to access the courts virtually for E-filing of cases, E-payment of court fees, virtual hearing of matters and delivery of rulings and judgments. This dissemination of information has also helped to subvert the misinformation on how the courts were operating during the pandemic, especially amongst litigants. 3. Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules gazetted for implementation: IDLO supported development of the Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules in 2019, through a Legislative Drafter in the Rules Committee to support the draftingand validation of pending rules. However, the finalised Rules had been pending review and gazettement by the Office of the Attorney General (OAG). On 22 February 2020, the Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules were finally gazetted for implementation. The Rules simplify processes in the handling of civil matters and provide clarity on provisions of the Civil Procedure Act that have overtime been interpreted differently by the different courts. Full implementation ofthe Rules alongside the Act will accelerate adjudication of civil matters and contribute to reduction of case backlog in the courts currently handling civil cases. 4. Guidelines for implementation of the Access to Information Act developed and adopted: IDLO partnered with the Commission on Administration of Justice (CAJ) to develop Guidelines to aid implementation of Access to Information Act, 2016. This was through stakeholder consultations with the CAJ, various Government officesincluding the Office of the Attorney General (OAG), the Kenya Law Reform Commission (KLRC), Ministry of Information, Kenya National Registration Bureau of Statistics, and CSOs. 5. Framework for the implementation of the Legal Audit Report developed: IDLO supported KLRC and the Council of Governors (COG) to develop the Implementation Framework for the Legal Audit Report, as a road map for implementation of County level policy, legislative and administrative reforms with a view to strengthening devolution in Kenya. The Framework developed to operationalise the findings of the Legal Audit of the National and County policies and laws developed in 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
